1.0    Introduction

The Rohm and Haas Company Croydon Plant (Rohm and Haas Company is a wholly owned subsidiary of The Dow Chemical Company) is committed to operating and maintaining processes safely.  Our continuing work to prevent accidents and releases from occurring, as well as our preparations to respond to incidents should they occur, help to ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This summary provides an overview of the risk management activities at the Croydon Plant, and a discussion of our response to the EPAs Risk Management Program. 



2.0    General Facility Information



The Croydon Plant is a specialty chemical manufacturing facility located in Bristol Township, Bucks County, Pennsylvania.  The plant was built in 1969 and is part of a larger site, the Bristol Site originally built in 1909.  Today, the Bristol Site includes the Croydon plant, the Bristol Polymers solvent based acrylic production plant, and corporate engineering group.  The Croydon Plant shares many of the services provided at the Bristol Site including a unified emergency response network.  Of the total site area of 800 acres, only 250 acres are in actual use with the balance of the area utilized as open space accommodating a variety of plant and animal species.



The Croydon Plant produces over 150 different products which are sold to other manufacturers who use them as key components in consumer products.  These products are aqueous based acrylic emulsions which are used as coatings and binders.  Emulsion coating products are used in interior and exterior latex paint and traffic line formulations.  In addition, these products are found in floor polishes, adhesives, inks,cosmetics, coatings and binders for paper products,cement and concrete.  Because the products are water based, they are more environmentally friendly than solvent based coatings.



The Croydon Plant produces more than 350 million pounds of product annually.   The pla

nt's production units employ 115 people.  The plant works with the Bristol Site contributing to a variety of charitable organizations within the community.   The Bristol Site works closely with its Community Advisory Council (CAC) to identify community needs and concerns.



3.0    EPA Risk Management Program



In a series of rules promulgated between 1994 and 1998, updated in 2004 and 2017, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency established the Risk Management Program (RMP) under the Clean Air Act containing a list of toxic and flammable chemicals.  Facilities that manage more than a threshold amount of a listed chemical are subject to the RMP.  Covered facilities must assess the risks associated with their management of the listed chemicals and produce a plan to prevent releases and accidents.  In order to assist in emergency planning, covered facilities must evaluate a worst case and alternative case scenarios that would result from the release of a listed chemical.



4.0    Regulated Substances



The Croydon Plant uses two RMP toxic chemicals at threshold quantities: 

Acrylonitrile monomer - Storage tank, railcar, and 3 covered reactors

Vinyl Acetate monomer - Drum storage only



**Note - Aqueous ammonia has been removed from coverage as described in previous submissions.   Per EPAs FAQs, water can be subtracted from the aqueous ammonia inventory on site, leaving the site below the ammonia threshold of 20,000 pounds.



5.0    The Rohm and Haas Croydon Plant Accident Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps  



Croydon Plant maintains a number of accident prevention programs in order to ensure safe operation of all processes.  The Croydon Plant complies with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) rule, which is nearly identical to EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. Additionally, the Plant follows corporate and plant-specific safety standards, (which in some cases are more stringent than the OSHA general safety standards), while also compl

ying with EPA, DOT, and state requirements.   The following items are part of our ongoing program to prevent releases and incidents for RMP toxic chemicals as well as any other chemicals:  



5.1     Employee Participation -  Employees are involved in many activities to continuously improve plant safety.   Employees participate in safety committees, audits, design and pre-startup safety reviews, management of change reviews, process hazard analysis, training, procedure development and monthly safety meetings.   Employees make rounds to identify potential leaks or other safety hazards.   Employees use Dow Chemical electronic tools to communicate hazardous conditions to each other and management.



5.2    Process Hazard Analysis - A process hazard analysis technique known as RC/PHA (Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analysis) is used to identify and analyze the potential hazards associated with the chemicals and processes we use. And additional technique, Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA) is also used to analyze potential hazards.   Corrective action plans are developed and implemented as part of the analysis and updated a minimum of every three years.  Safety systems are designed into the processes.  These are designed to create several layers of protection, so that if one system fails other systems will maintain the process in a safe state.  These engineering and administrative controls help prevent releases of chemicals: 



    Redundant safety systems and instrumentation, particularly for tank level systems

    Automatic shutdown devices that are triggered if critical safety equipment malfunctions

    Secondary containment for storage tanks

    Alarm systems and automatic shutdown devices for critical control parameters 

    Pressure relief devices to prevent over pressurization

    Fire protection systems

    Operator attendance of unloading operations

    Permit system to control work in hazardous areas

    Work preplanning and safety reviews





5.3    Operating Procedures - Operati

ng procedures have been developed for all processes to ensure safe operation.  Employees who operate the manufacturing processes are included in the development, training, and periodic review of these procedures.   Our processes are ISO9001 certified. 



5.4    Employee Training - Training programs have been developed and implemented  to ensure that all affected employees understand the hazards of the chemicals used and the required safe handling procedures. Employees involved in operating the manufacturing processes are trained, tested, qualified, and certified at least once every 3 years as required by OSHA PSM and EPA RMP.     

  

5.5    Mechanical Integrity - The plant operates its mechanical integrity program as per the Dow Chemical GMISS (Global Mechanical Integrity Safety Standard) requirements.   The program was established to ensure the integrity of process equipment.  Elements of this program include:



    Identification and categorization of equipment and instrumentation

    Inspections and tests

    Establishment of inspection frequencies

    Development and application of maintenance procedures

    Training of maintenance personnel

    Documentation of tests and inspection results



5.6    Pre-Startup Safety Reviews - Safety reviews of new processes and major projects are conducted to ensure safe transition into the manufacturing process.  



5.7    Hot Work Permit - This system manages welding, cutting, brazing and other ignition sources throughout the plant to prevent fires and explosions. 



5.8    Management of Change - This procedure is in place to properly manage the changes involving processes, chemicals, technology, people, equipment or facilities.   MOCs are tracked in a Web based system developed by Dow Chemical.



5.9    Contractor Training and Safety Reviews - Contractors are evaluated prior working on the site to ensure they have the appropriate job skills, knowledge, training, and certification to perform their assigned work safely.  The safety performance of c

ontractors is reviewed on a periodic basis.  Contractors with unacceptable safety performance are not allowed to work onsite.



5.10    Incident Investigation - Any incidents or near misses involving the release of RMP covered hazardous materials are investigated by a team of skilled and knowledgeable plant personnel.  These investigations identify corrective actions, evaluate our management systems and are documented and communicated as appropriate throughout the company in a narrative report.  Any required corrective actions are tracked for timely completion.



5.11    Compliance Audits - Audits of our Process Safety Management System and RMP are conducted  every three years by the Dow corporate auditing group.  These audits review accident prevention activities to ensure the requirements of the programs are being met. 



6.0    Five Year Accident History



The Rohm and Haas Croydon Plant has had no events meeting the criteria established by the RMP rule during the last five years.



7.0    Emergency Response Program 



The Rohm and Haas Croydon Plant plan is incorporated into a unified emergency response plan for the Bristol Facility.  This Consolidated Emergency Response Plan is  coordinated with the Bucks (Pennsylvania) and Burlington County (New Jersey) Local Emergency Planning Committees (LEPC), Bristol Township, and Croydon Fire Company.  The site Emergency Services Leader serves on the Bucks County LEPC as an industry representative.   New employees are trained on handling emergencies prior to working in a process area and plant personnel review the plan annually.  The Bristol Facility has an extensive alarm system, which is monitored by ADT.   The facility has emergency response team members onsite at all times.   ADT will call the site or the fire department directly depending on the type of alarm.   The facility has an on-site fire brigade, mobile fire suppression vehicles, Hazmat Technicians as well as certified emergency medical personnel. The site has mobil

e foam capabilities to control vapor release.  All emergency response personnel receive ongoing training.  The facility has 24-hour emergency response capabilities and can respond to both on-site and transportation off-site hazardous materials releases.  The facility is also part of the Dow Chemical regional response network and provides offsite response into the community when requested on a mutual aid basis.  Facility emergency response personnel have radio communications with the Bucks County 911 center.  Emergency response personnel can be self dispatched, or dispatched through the County 911 center.  The facility is also able to access the Community Alerting Network (CAN) through the Bristol Township Emergency Management Department.   Plant drill and mutual aid response activities are practiced annually.   



8.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



The  focus on safety is strong throughout the Rohm and Haas Company and The Dow Chemical Company.  Rohm and Haas continuously looks for ways to reduce risks and to improve safety performance.  This includes improvements in control technology, inspections, training, and maintenance of process equipment. Croydon Plant safety program is integrated into all parts of plant operation and involves the identification and implementation of  ways to improve safety performance.   The plant has evaluated its operations against Dow Chemical process safety standards and is changing where necessary to meet these internal standards. 



The plant has implemented the additional requirements of RMP in the 2017 changes of the RMP regulations.   In 2018 we met with local fire departments and the LEPC to review our RMP chemicals and hazards and to explain the 2017 changes to the RMP regulations.   We have begun evaluation of the other 2017 requirements which are due in 2021.
